{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3658731,"name":"Donovan White","username":"comandd","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T18:32:31.326Z","cooked":"

Any teams out there interested in a atmega328p based led controller for 5v addressable LED strips? I‚Äôve noticed the REV blinkin and CTRE CANdle are good led controllers however they are quite expensive and usually are rather difficult to program or they don‚Äôt have a ton of customizability. I‚Äôm just asking here to see if it would be worth developing one and making it for sale.

I‚Äôm aware there are good options for on-robot LEDs, but would having one that can do other things such as robot-cart lighting, pit lighting, etc, be of any use to teams? I appreciate any feedback!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-06-20T18:32:31.326Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":241,"readers_count":240,"score":128.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503428,"topic_slug":"open-source-programmable-led-controller","display_username":"Donovan White","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76228,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2024"},"post_url":"/t/open-source-programmable-led-controller/503428/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3658751,"name":"Tom","username":"Tom_Neu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_neu/{size}/222407_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T19:46:34.202Z","cooked":"

You can control the LEDs via connecting to power to a VRM and programming with a roborio, so I don‚Äôt know what is the advantage to using something like the blinkin or CANdle

Former head of software, strategy and development"},"post_url":"/t/open-source-programmable-led-controller/503428/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3658758,"name":"Matthew L","username":"Another_Person1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a87d85/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T20:18:17.385Z","cooked":"

If I were you, I might reconsider using the atmega328p as it is becoming phased out and is not recommended for new designs according to Microchip.

I‚Äôm aware of that, just using it as an example for the concept and maybe the initial prototype.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-06-20T20:19:31.705Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":68.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503428,"topic_slug":"open-source-programmable-led-controller","display_username":"Donovan White","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":75810,"username":"Another_Person1","name":"Matthew L","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a87d85/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76228,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2024"},"post_url":"/t/open-source-programmable-led-controller/503428/4","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3658820,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T21:46:31.953Z","cooked":"

If you want customizable, the PixelBlaze platform has some ridiculously powerful pattern configuration and installation tools. https://electromage.com/docs/intro-to-mapping . This also has an open source library to tap into this capability on custom boards.

For things on carts and off-robot, the WLED platform is ESP32 based with good configuration apps, which provides open source budget options. Or, for many smaller projects a $5 Pi Pico works.

As for goals, anytime you aim to undercut pricing, you‚Äôll probably run into the same problems that showcase why it‚Äôs expensive, but only after having sunk development costs. The bulk of component cost in Blinkin and CANdle are in power management for high current outputs on ridiculously unclean power in a robot environment. If you‚Äôre not operating on a robot, the majority of those costs are unnecessary, and undercutting things is pretty trivial. But, by the same metric, cheaper, standard components already exist.
Not trying to discourage product development as a summer project: But just be aware that this particular goal is probably not the right one to chase after.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-06-20T21:46:31.953Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":169,"readers_count":168,"score":63.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503428,"topic_slug":"open-source-programmable-led-controller","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://electromage.com/docs/intro-to-mapping","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/open-source-programmable-led-controller/503428/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3658825,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T21:51:13.109Z","cooked":"

Don‚Äôt ask me why, but I seem to have a bit of a passion for addressable LED‚Äôs and controllers. Just ask my wife.
328p‚Äôs are fine for smaller setups, but they lack memory to do much more than a couple dozen LEDs. They struggle with more than one strand, but can handle it if you are super careful in your code. They have one advantage though, they have +5v logic signal out.

I would suggest looking into some of the simple esp8266, or even better, esp32, boards. For example, we ran an esp8266 D1 Mini board, powered by a Polulu +5v regulator to drive a couple of strip on our bot this year.
The 8266 is capable of running your own home brewed code or something as sweet as WLED. It only has +3.3v logic out, so you need to keep the run to the first LED quite short. If that is not possible, simply add a logic level shifter and you are good to go. For example, this one by Adafruit.

If you step to an esp32 you can drive multiple strings quite easily, even under WLED. Again, level shifting might need to take place.

We controlled our LED code via serial packets sent from the Rio to the controller over USB. Simple, sweet, and candy for the eyes.

Aw, @tekdemo beat me to it

Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T21:51:43.649Z","cooked":"

I am thinking make one that use ESP32 and SPI strips connected via CAN.

However I haven‚Äôt figure out best way of implementing control. The most flexible method would be allow pixel level update. However this could create significant amount of CAN traffic which could impact more critical stuff on the robot like motor controllers.

Alternatively I could have several preset pattern on ESP32 and no pixel level control.

Which one do you prefer? Need some suggestions?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-06-20T21:51:43.649Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":132,"readers_count":131,"score":76.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503428,"topic_slug":"open-source-programmable-led-controller","display_username":"Nathan Zhou","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66330,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Fennekinü¶ä is so cute!"},"post_url":"/t/open-source-programmable-led-controller/503428/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3658841,"name":"Pedro Braga","username":"predobrega","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T22:47:45.937Z","cooked":"

CAN based control and/or support for 12v LED strips.

I think they also have onboard storage for LED patterns, which can reduce cpu load on the Rio, but I don‚Äôt know how much of an actual concern that is on your average robot.

comandd:

I‚Äôve noticed the REV blinkin and CTRE CANdle are good led controllers however they are quite expensive and usually are rather difficult to program or they don‚Äôt have a ton of customizability.

The Blinkin firmware is open source fwiw.

We used pwm strips this year hooked up to the rio. I‚Äôm pretty sure they were 5v but you could probably make/buy a circuit for 12-5v.
For off bot we got an esp32 with wled for our driver station.

One of the reasons I prefer the esp32/esp8266 controllers is that you can create dozens of animations using the Adafruit Neopixel libraries.

Welcome! You‚Äôll get a lot of advice on this topic for sure :). I can speak with a tiny bit of experience in this space.

comandd:

usually are rather difficult to program or they don‚Äôt have a ton of customizability

First things first - these are competing goals - as you decrease programming complexity, you also decrease customizability. If nothing else, before outlaying money on hardware, I‚Äôd recommend mocking up your development environment and user interface that hits the ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù between these. Getting that reviewed and ‚Äúright‚Äù will be a pre-step to success.

Some experience I bring to the table: I‚Äôve done very similar exercises for my own team.

We only made a few prototypes, but I did price out costs for more. At a small (500 units) production run, here‚Äôs a quick rundown of costs:

  1. PCB, components, assembly, shipping from factory->my house - $15/each
  2. Up-front engineering cost: 40 hours, which I‚Äôll bill myself at $100/hour - $4000 total, or $8 per unit.
  3. Let‚Äôs assume another $3 per unit for packaging and shipping.
  4. Case, 3d printed - $1 per unit, plus probably about $2 per unit of labor to maintain the printer and assemble the final units

With no software support, we‚Äôre conservatively at $29 already minimum costs, with no profit margin to help you expand the business. That‚Äôs getting real darn close to Rev‚Äôs ~$50 blinkin.

But, then again, consider that you‚Äôll have to also pay for:

  1. Logistics - someone‚Äôs gotta put labels on boxes and drop them in the mailbox
  2. Software - I just used the STM32 Cube IDE to program - if you‚Äôre inventing a layer on top, that will take more engineering time and effort
  3. Ongoing hardware support - if you ship hardware, you have to account for the fact some hardware will break. You‚Äôll need to spend time troubleshooting with customers, providing prompt responses, and shipping them new hardware gratis
  4. Ongoing software support - See above, but for whatever software you ship.

Trying to break into an existing already competitive market with a lower-cost solution is impossible unless you have some really innovative cost reduction. IMO, the easier way to break in is to innovate something that‚Äôs better than most of what‚Äôs on the market, and then charge a premium for it. Especially for the LED market (where a team can always fall back on a $5 arduino and a bit of soldering), that would be my ticket to success.

ALL that being said‚Ä¶ I still encourage you to start the journey! There‚Äôs a ton to be learned even in just the initial engineering, and if you do nothing but make a prototype your team can still benefit from using it next season.

I got this working!!

Custom CAN sensor - some good progress Control System
It‚Äôs here! I got this mostly working, only some minor bugfix! A CAN enabled Addressable LED Controller! Fully customizable! This controller have support of built in pattern or pixel by pixel update from roboRIO. Please read the full documentation for how to set it up and how to create your own pattern! Be very careful with pixel by pixel mode (Mode 255) as it could create a huge amount of CAN traffic (45% CAN util for 60 pixel). It is recommanded that you create your own pattern in ESP32 and‚Ä¶

also I feel like this can be port to atmega328p using a MCP2515.
